description: A variant of errant, from Middle English erraunt [and other forms], from Anglo-Norman erraunt, from Old French errant, the present participle of errer (“to walk (to); to wander (to); (figuratively) to travel, voyage”), and then:

The original sense was sense 3 (“roving around, wandering”). Due to the word being used to describe disreputable persons who wandered about (for example, arrant knave and arrant thief), it came to be used as an intensifier (sense 1: “complete; downright; utter”) and to have a negative meaning (sense 2: “very bad; despicable”).

adjectives.description: arrant (comparative more arrant or arranter, superlative most arrant or arrantest)

entries.meaning: (chiefly with a negative connotation, dated) Complete; downright; utter.
examples: Synonyms: out-and-out, unmitigated; see also Thesaurus:total

entries.meaning: Obsolete form of errant (“roving around; wandering”).
